thread.title: Europa League wrap: Lyon scrape past Roma while Schalke land last eight spot after fightback in Gladbach
thread.title_full: Europa League wrap: Lyon scrape past Roma while Schalke land last eight spot after fightback in Gladbach

author: Alex Richards
title: Europa League wrap: Lyon scrape past Roma while Schalke land last eight spot after fightback in Gladbach
text:
OL celebrate their success in Rome (Photo: REUTERS) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Olympique Lyonnais were beaten 2-1 by Roma but still represent the greatest threat to Manchester United’s Europa League hopes after securing their spot in Friday’s draw for the last eight. 
Buoyed by Alexandre Lacazette’s injury time rocket in France a week ago, OL travelled to the Italian capital with a 4-2 lead to defend against Luciano Spalletti’s attack-minded outfit. 
And after Antonio Rudiger had hit the woodwork for the home side, Bruno Genesio’s men took advantage of an open start in the Stadio Olimpico, when Mouctar Diakhaby capitalised on poor defending to head home Mathieu Valbuena’s free kick. 
Roma needed a quick response, and Spalletti will have been delighted to see it come within 60 seconds, as Kevin Strootman bundled over the line a Daniele de Rossi cross. 
The Dutch midfielder would twice be denied by OL keeper Anthony Lopes, as would Edin Dzeko and Mathieu Valbuena, but the Portuguese couldn’t deny his own teammate on the hour mark, as Stephan El Shaarawy’s low cross was turned home by Lucas Tousart. The crucial moment - Diakhaby heads home (Photo: REUTERS) The young defender celebrates with experienced Christophe Jallet (Photo: AFP/Getty Images) Roma's late push just wasn't quite enough (Photo: AFP/Getty Images) 
That offered fresh hope to the Italians, for whom substituted El Shaarawy failed to find the bottom corner minutes later. 
Edin Dzeko would have a goal disallowed for offside, while veteran Italy star Francesco Totti stepped from the bench to try and force home a goal for the hosts that would have put them through. 
However, Genesio’s young French side held firm to land their spot in the last eight. Anthony Lopes takes the acclaim of his teammates after a massive showing (Photo: REUTERS) Mahmoud Dahoud struck a stormer as Gladbach went 2-0 up at home to Schalke... (Photo: Bongarts/Getty Images) ...But Nabil Bentaleb led Schalke's fightback (Photo: AFP/Getty Images) 
Tottenham’s on-loan midfield Nabil Bentaleb was the hero in Germany, as Schalke fought back from two goals down to knockout Borussia Monchengladbach on away goals. 
After a 1-1 draw at the Veltins Arena last week, Gladbach took control of the game thanks to goals from Andreas Christensen and a 25-yard stonker from young star Mahmoud Dahoud. 
But after a half-time dressing down from Markus Wienzierl, Schalke hit back, first through Leon Goretzka and then a coolly-taken penalty from Bentaleb to send them into the last eight at the expense of their Bundesliga rivals. Schalke saw off their German rivals (Photo: AFP/Getty Images) Kasper Dolberg's goal proved decisive for Ajax (Photo: REUTERS) 
Another Premier League loanee on target was Chelsea’s Bertrand Traore, who struck the opener as Ajax beat Copenhagen 2-0 in Amsterdam to secure their quarter-final spot. 
Traore struck after just nine minutes to make it 2-2 on aggregate and after Kasper Dolberg’s penalty on the stroke of half-time, Peter Bosz’s side held out to see off the Danish champions. 
Elsewhere, Anderlecht beat APOEL 1-0 to knock out the Cypriots 2-0 on aggregate, while Genk, Celta Vigo and Besiktas also made their ways into the next round, the Turkish champions inspired by Ryan Babel, who scored a brace, as they thrashed Olympiacos 4-1 in Turkey. poll loading Will Manchester United reach the Europa League final? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
